title: SEO (Search Engine Optimization)
definition: The process of making a website more visible in search results, also termed improving search rankings.

title: API (Application Programming Interface)
definition: A set of functions and protocols that allows the creation of applications that access features or data of an operating system, application, or service.

title: AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML)
definition: A method of building interactive applications by sending and retrieving data from a server asynchronously without interfering with the existing page.

title: DOM (Document Object Model)
definition: An API for HTML and XML documents that defines the logical structure of documents and the way they can be accessed and manipulated.

title: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets)
definition: A stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML.

title: HTML (HyperText Markup Language)
definition: The standard markup language for creating web pages and web applications.

title: JavaScript
definition: A programming language that enables dynamic content updates, interactive forms, and multimedia on web pages.

title: Node.js
definition: A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine, allowing JavaScript to run server-side.

title: Promise
definition: An object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.

title: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol)
definition: The protocol used for transferring hypertext requests and information on the internet.

title: HTTPS (HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure)
definition: An extension of HTTP that uses encryption protocols to secure data transfer on the internet.

title: REST (Representational State Transfer)
definition: An architectural style for designing networked applications, relying on stateless communication and predefined operations.

title: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)
definition: A lightweight data-interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write and for machines to parse and generate.

title: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)
definition: A mechanism that allows restricted resources on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the one the page originated from.

title: Webpack
definition: A static module bundler for modern JavaScript applications.

title: Babel
definition: A JavaScript compiler that allows you to use next-generation JavaScript today.

title: TypeScript
definition: A strongly typed programming language that builds on JavaScript, giving you better tooling at any scale.

title: Event Loop
definition: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.

title: Accessibility
definition: The practice of making web content usable by people of all abilities and disabilities.

title: Viewport
definition: The user's visible area of a web page, which changes based on the device and screen size.

title: Local Storage
definition: A web storage API that allows developers to store data in the browser with no expiration time.

title: Session Storage
definition: A web storage API that stores data for the duration of the page session, which is cleared once the tab is closed.

title: Cookie
definition: A small piece of data stored on the user's device by the web browser while browsing a website.

title: Service Worker
definition: A script that runs in the background of your browser, enabling offline support, push notifications, and background data syncing.

title: Progressive Web App (PWA)
definition: A type of application software delivered through the web, built using common web technologies, and intended to work on any platform.

title: Responsive Design
definition: An approach to web design that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and screen sizes.

title: Grid Layout
definition: A CSS layout system optimized for creating two-dimensional grid-based designs.

title: Flexbox
definition: A CSS layout module that provides a more efficient way to lay out, align, and distribute space among items in a container.

title: Viewport Meta Tag
definition: A meta tag in HTML that gives instructions to the browser on how to control the page's dimensions and scaling.

title: WebSocket
definition: A protocol that enables two-way communication between a client and server over a single, long-lived connection.

title: GraphQL
definition: A query language for your API that allows clients to request exactly the data they need.

title: Middleware
definition: Software that acts as a bridge between an operating system or database and applications, especially on a network.

title: Virtual DOM
definition: A programming concept where a virtual representation of a UI is kept in memory and synced with the real DOM by a library like React.

title: Hoisting
definition: A behavior in JavaScript where variables and function declarations are moved to the top of their containing scope during compilation.

title: Event Bubbling
definition: An event propagation method where an event starts from the target element and then bubbles up to the ancestors.

title: Event Capturing
definition: An event propagation method where an event starts from the ancestor elements down to the target element.

title: WebAssembly
definition: A binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine that runs alongside JavaScript, providing a way to execute code at near-native speed.

title: Polyfill
definition: A JavaScript library that provides modern functionality on older browsers that do not natively support it.

title: Lazy Loading
definition: A design pattern that delays the loading of non-critical resources until they are needed.

title: Infinite Scrolling
definition: A technique that automatically loads more content as the user scrolls down a page.

title: Shadow DOM
definition: A web standard that enables encapsulation of DOM and styles for web components.

title: Web Component
definition: A set of web platform APIs that allow you to create reusable and encapsulated custom elements.

title: Content Security Policy (CSP)
definition: A security feature that helps prevent attacks such as cross-site scripting (XSS) by defining allowed content sources.

title: Single Page Application (SPA)
definition: A web application that dynamically rewrites a single web page with new data from the server, rather than loading entire new pages.

title: Server-Side Rendering (SSR)
definition: A rendering method where HTML is rendered on the server and sent to the client, improving SEO and load times.

title: Client-Side Rendering (CSR)
definition: A rendering method where JavaScript renders the content directly in the browser, after downloading the necessary resources.

title: Progressive Enhancement
definition: A web development strategy that emphasizes core web page content and functionality while gradually adding more features.

title: Graceful Degradation
definition: A design approach that focuses on building advanced features for modern browsers while ensuring a basic experience on older ones.

title: Content Delivery Network (CDN)
definition: A system of distributed servers that deliver web content to a user based on geographic location, improving load times.

title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
definition: A security vulnerability that allows attackers to inject malicious scripts into websites viewed by other users.
